title: A few small cracks appear in Trump’s solid Republican support
text:
AFP/Getty Images Donald Trump understandably seems to be worried about the latest scandal.

It hasn’t even been one week since we read the first reports suggesting that Donald Trump pressured Ukraine’s President Volodymyr Zelensky to fabricate a case against Joe Biden and his son.

On Tuesday afternoon, we learned that the House of Representatives is beginning an impeachment inquiry into Trump. After more than two and a half years of anguishing over how to respond to Trump’s assault on constitutional democracy, things suddenly seem to moving at light speed for Democrats.

Republicans changing?

Perhaps more importantly, something may be changing for Republicans as well.

Former Ohio Gov. John Kasich tweeted on Monday that “I have a simple message for GOP members of Congress: Where are you? Are you hiding under a rock? This is not political. This is our national security we’re talking about here. The intel committees in Congress need to review the information. Follow the law!”

We’ve gotten used to the idea that nothing will be enough to move Republicans to take action when it comes to Trump scandals, so Kasich’s words seemed unlikely to have any impact. But this time Kasich didn’t seem to be howling into the wind.

On Tuesday, the Senate voted unanimously, 100-0, to pass a resolution calling on the Trump administration to provide House and Senate intelligence committees with a copy of a whistleblower complaint that reportedly relates to Trump’s efforts to enlist Zelensky’s assistance in winning re-election.

Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell of Kentucky agreed with New York Democratic Sen. Chuck Schumer’s request for an immediate vote on the nonbinding resolution, bypassing ordinary debate. This is unusual, to say the least.

Working with Democrats

It’s not exactly standard procedure for McConnell to help out Democrats — and it may have had an impact. The White House, which had been blocking transmittal of the whistleblower complaint to Congress, has now reportedly dropped its objections and is negotiating to allow the whistleblower to speak to members of Congress.

McConnell isn’t the only Republican who seems to be interested in Congress getting access to the relevant information. Republican Sen. Mitt Romney of Utah said on Twitter that “If the President asked or pressured Ukraine’s president to investigate his political rival…it would be troubling in the extreme. Critical for the facts to come out.”

Republican Sen. Cory Gardner of Colorado, who faces a tough campaign for re-election in 2020, said when asked if he supports the president, “Let’s find out what’s happening. Let’s get to the bottom of this.”

That doesn’t sound like the routine we’ve gotten used to each time a new Trump scandal emerges when Republicans robotically fall in line behind the president.

The math of removal

This is intriguing, of course, because impeachment can only have a chance of leading to Trump’s removal from office if Republicans are on board. Assuming that the House votes to impeach and all 47 Democratic senators decide against the president in a Senate trial, it would take 20 Republican senators to end Trump’s presidency.

That still seems like a long shot, to say the least. But, as I mentioned, things are moving really quickly, and no one can say for sure where this will end up.

If the reports are correct — and some of what we know comes from Trump’s own public admissions — the president engaged in a massive abuse of power that depended on undermining the legitimacy of U.S. elections by pressuring a foreign country to help him win re-election.

Not for the first time, Trump seems to be acting more like a caricatured version of a mob boss, using whatever leverage is available to him (in the case, military aid to Ukraine provided by Congress through legislation) in an effort to advance his personal interest in place of the national interest.

Trump understandably seems worried — there is a report that he asked Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi if they could work something out regarding the whistleblower complaint (Pelosi, a California Democrat, reportedly responded by saying to Trump: “Tell your people to obey the law”).

Taking control of narrative

Pelosi seems to be making a move to take control of the narrative. That will be challenging for several reasons.

First, Trump is a skilled manipulator when it comes to the media — and he has Fox News and the right-wing media megaphone behind him. Second, Pelosi will have to keep Democrats organized and on point. It will be essential to stay focused.

If impeachment proceedings advance on too many fronts, the thread of the story could get lost. The Ukraine scandal is worth emphasizing — it is easy to understand, it is explosive, it is already damning, it is ongoing as it relates to the 2020 campaign, and it is likely to get worse for Trump.

Gaining Republican support for impeachment would be a tall order.

Here, Pelosi and congressional Democrats will need help from Kasich and other prominent Republicans. It could be useful to have former President George W. Bush and other Republicans with household names make the same point Kasich made — that the allegations against Trump raise national security concerns that go to the heart of our constitutional republic.

It will be essential for prominent Republicans in Congress — Romney, for instance — to remain objective rather than serving as a Praetorian Guard personally loyal to the president rather than the Constitution (as some unfortunately are doing).

Highest stakes

This is a test for our constitutional system, and the stakes couldn’t be higher. If Trump weathers this storm, he will quite reasonably believe that he enjoys carte blanche to use whatever underhanded tactics, to recruit assistance from as many foreign actors as he likes, in order to win re-election.

On the bright side, for all Americans — Republicans, Democrats, and Independents — who want to preserve our system and hold a free and fair election in 2020, there is now a glimmer of hope.
